posts.post_content:
@ Iwachiten  
  
[Stave Off](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stave Off) doesn't interact with Day of Judgment  
  
I can't believe how many people make that mistake, it even says right below [Stave Off](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stave Off) that is doesn't work that way.  
  
Does Day of Judgment deal Damage?  
No  
Does Day of Judgment Enchant or Equip?  
No  
Does Day of Judgment Block?  
No  
Does Day of Judgment Target?  
No  
  
It destroys the creature, not the same as dealing damage, and it doesn't target it, it doesn't work with [Stave Off](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stave Off) at all.  
  
Damage, when you deal damage, as indicated by the phrase "deal 'X' damage" you place damage counters on a creature, if these counters would be greater than the toughness of the creature, the creature is destroyed, damage actually doesn't modify toughness (otherwise you could kill a [Spearbreaker Behemoth](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Spearbreaker Behemoth) with 2 [Lightning Bolt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lightning Bolt)s). Creatures with protection negate those damage counters being placed on it.  
  
Only cards that say "Enchant" or "Equip" s... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Stave Off doesn't interact with Day of Judgment

I can't believe how many people make that mistake, it even says right below Stave Off that is doesn't work that way.

Does Day of Judgment deal Damage?
No
Does Day of Judgment Enchant or Equip?
No
Does Day of Judgment Block?
No
Does Day of Judgment Target?
No

It destroys the creature, not the same as dealing damage, and it doesn't target it, it doesn't work with Stave Off at all.

Damage, when you deal damage, as indicated by the phrase "deal 'X' damage" you place damage counters on a creature, if these counters would be greater than the toughness of the creature, the creature is destroyed, damage actually doesn't modify toughness (otherwise you could kill a Spearbreaker Behemoth with 2 Lightning Bolts). Creatures with protection negate those damage counters being placed on it.

posts.post_content:
Well, there's not much for me to say about the power level of the card itself. Wrath of God has proven itself to be a powerful card with applications in many formats. It's been a staple in white decks since the game began, and I don't expect that to change any time soon.  
  
Personally, however, I am not a huge fan of Day of Judgment's spot in the color pie. I think "Destroy all creatures" should be a black ability more than a white ability. From where I'm standing, the [Hallowed Burial](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Hallowed Burial)/[Final Judgment](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Final Judgment) version has a much whiter feel to it--all of white's other removal is "nonlethal", exiling, tucking, or otherwise disabling the creature rather than outright killing it. White mana can be destructive, of course, but it seems to me like a true white board sweeper should be more like [Planar Cleansing](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Planar Cleansing) for a *clean* sweep, as opposed to a living-creatures-only [Wrath of God](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wrath of God) affair. Also, it's a little awkward ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
Well, there's not much for me to say about the power level of the card itself. Wrath of God has proven itself to be a powerful card with applications in many formats. It's been a staple in white decks since the game began, and I don't expect that to change any time soon.

Personally, however, I am not a huge fan of Day of Judgment's spot in the color pie. I think "Destroy all creatures" should be a black ability more than a white ability. From where I'm standing, the Hallowed Burial/Final Judgment version has a much whiter feel to it--all of white's other removal is "nonlethal", exiling, tucking, or otherwise disabling the creature rather than outright killing it. White mana can be destructive, of course, but it seems to me like a true white board sweeper should be more like Planar Cleansing for a clean sweep, as opposed to a living-creatures-only Wrath of God affair. posts.post_content:
@Xineombine  
  
"An indestructible permanent can't be destroyed, but it can still be sacrificed, exiled, put into a graveyard, and so on."  
  
It's a static ability, destroy effects just don't do anything.  
  
"Protection from everything" means the following: -- [Progenitus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Progenitus) can't be blocked. -- Progenitus can't be enchanted or equipped. -- Progenitus can't be the target of spells or abilities. -- All damage that would be dealt to Progenitus is prevented.  
Progenitus can still be affected by effects that don't target it or deal damage to it (such as Wrath of God).  
  
Both cards totally explain how they work.  
  
[Black Sun's Zenith](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Black Sun's Zenith) would work though, if you did it for enough. Any creature with zero toughness is put into it's owners graveyard as a state based effect.
posts.html:
@Xineombine

"An indestructible permanent can't be destroyed, but it can still be sacrificed, exiled, put into a graveyard, and so on."

It's a static ability, destroy effects just don't do anything.

"Protection from everything" means the following: -- Progenitus can't be blocked. -- Progenitus can't be enchanted or equipped. -- Progenitus can't be the target of spells or abilities. -- All damage that would be dealt to Progenitus is prevented.
Progenitus can still be affected by effects that don't target it or deal damage to it (such as Wrath of God).

Both cards totally explain how they work.

Black Sun's Zenith would work though, if you did it for enough. Any creature with zero toughness is put into it's owners graveyard as a state based effect.

posts.post_content: I'm pretty sure than since this card can destroy a card with "Protection from Everything" that means [Avacyn, Angel of Hope](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Avacyn, Angel of Hope)'s ability never triggers, for indestructible prevents targeted destruction (ie [Doom blade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doom blade)), not non-targeted removal (ie this card, [Black sun's zenith](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Black sun's zenith), [Damnation](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Damnation). etc)

I hate seeing this from across the table. Lately, I have seen the scenario where they will first call [Batterskull](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Batterskull) back to their hand, then use this, then put Batterskull back on the field.   
  
This is the card that gives White decks late-game staying power if most of their weenies have been dispatched. 5/5 for usability, but damn, do I hate seeing my opponent play it =/

posts.post_content:
The lack of anti-regeneration in this card just saved me recently.  
  
I was playing G/W and had a Birds of Paradise, a Strangleroot Geist (with a +1/+1 counter on it), and most importantly, a Thrun, The Last Troll. The other guy had 7 more life than me and like 8 creatures out including a couple fatties.   
  
I had DOJ in my hand just waiting for the perfect moment, and it came up. I killed all his creatures and regenerated my troll. He drew nothing relevant in the next turn and I drew an Angelic Destiny. It was over two turns later.
posts.html:
